pullRequest.body:
---
Rationale:
* Reduces the risk of introduction of new unintentional import order dependencies
* Documents existing (potential) import order dependencies as linting exceptions
* Simplifies the identification and resolution of merge conflicts
* Establishes a standard format for imports

To verify that all modified lines in the last commit are import statements:

`% git diff HEAD~1 | grep '^[+-][^+-]' | cut -c2- | grep -v '^import '`

To verify that the total number of changes (additions and deletions) for any specific import statement is even:

`% git diff HEAD~1 | grep '^[+-][^+-]' | cut -c2- | sort | uniq -c | grep -v '[02468] import'`

<details>

```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

Given the previous experiment with sorting imports, besides building, an important feature that this PR should have is `!bench` showing that there is no regression.  For me, an improvement in performance is a necessary condition for such a change.
@adomani Agreed! Who has the ability to trigger a `!bench` run?

Anyone: simply write a comment consisting only of !bench and it should work (maybe it is more permissive, I don't really know).

However, the branch should pass CI (at least the `lake build` step).
!bench

Gee, don't trigger the bench after every push! Only when you are satisfied with your changes and have everything compiling.

@Parcly-Taxel I agree that running the benchmark after every push is usually unnecessary and can be skipped until you're confident in the changes. However, for this particular case, I needed to measure performance after each commit to track incremental impacts (see discussion above). If there's a more efficient way to capture these measurements on a per-commit basis, or if this process is affecting the benchmarking infrastructure, please let me know. Are you the one managing the benchmarking infrastructure?
!bench

> Looking at the benchmark still shows an overall regression. (The "instructions" metric reports about 60*10⁹ additional instructions.) This is large enough that I don't think we should land this as-is. Can you look at this again?

Update:

After the latest set of changes this PR now achieves an overall reduction of 11*10⁹ instructions compared to the state before it. While the percentage reduction is small, I believe we now can rule out the possibility of an overall regression at least. Do you agree, @adomani & @grunweg?

If so, I'll rebase on `master` and ensure this PR remains free of merge conflicts with `master` going forward.

Please let me know if there's anything else I can do.

I'll work on further reducing the instruction count on a per-file basis and addressing the current import order dependencies (those in the exceptions file), but I suggest handling these in follow-up PRs.

Since this PR is performance neutral, I don't see a strong argument against merging it. I wonder if this is an efficient way use of everybody's time, as reviewing a diff of several hundred lines is always daunting and I'm how not sure how big the benefits are. I wouldn't object to merging this one, though.

<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

Given the previous experiment with sorting imports, besides building, an important feature that this PR should have is `!bench` showing that there is no regression.  For me, an improvement in performance is a necessary condition for such a change.
@adomani Agreed! Who has the ability to trigger a `!bench` run?

Anyone: simply write a comment consisting only of !bench and it should work (maybe it is more permissive, I don't really know).

However, the branch should pass CI (at least the `lake build` step).

Gee, don't trigger the bench after every push! Only when you are satisfied with your changes and have everything compiling.

However, for this particular case, I needed to measure performance after each commit to track incremental impacts (see discussion above). If there's a more efficient way to capture these measurements on a per-commit basis, or if this process is affecting the benchmarking infrastructure, please let me know. > Looking at the benchmark still shows an overall regression. (The "instructions" metric reports about 60*10⁹ additional instructions.) This is large enough that I don't think we should land this as-is. Can you look at this again?

Update:

After the latest set of changes this PR now achieves an overall reduction of 11*10⁹ instructions compared to the state before it. While the percentage reduction is small, I believe we now can rule out the possibility of an overall regression at least. Do you agree, @adomani & @grunweg?

If so, I'll rebase on `master` and ensure this PR remains free of merge conflicts with `master` going forward.

Please let me know if there's anything else I can do.

I'll work on further reducing the instruction count on a per-file basis and addressing the current import order dependencies (those in the exceptions file), but I suggest handling these in follow-up PRs.

Since this PR is performance neutral, I don't see a strong argument against merging it. I wonder if this is an efficient way use of everybody's time, as reviewing a diff of several hundred lines is always daunting and I'm how not sure how big the benefits are. I wouldn't object to merging this one, though.
!bench
